australian-magpie.description: The Australian magpie is a medium-sized black and white passerine bird native to Australia and southern New Guinea.
australian-magpie.habitat: Found in a variety of habitats across Australia, including urban areas, farmlands, and forests.
australian-magpie.diet: Omnivorous, feeding on insects, worms, small animals, and some plant matter.
funFacts: Known for their beautiful and complex vocalizations
Can recognize and remember individual human faces

laughing-kookaburra.description: The laughing kookaburra is a large terrestrial tree kingfisher native to eastern Australia.
laughing-kookaburra.habitat: Woodland territories, open eucalyptus forests, and park lands.
laughing-kookaburra.diet: Carnivorous, eating mice, snakes, insects, small reptiles, and the young of other birds.

images.caption: Laughing Kookaburra perched on a branch

funFacts: Known for its distinctive laughing call
Can live for up to 20 years in the wild

superb-fairywren.description: The superb fairywren is a passerine bird in the Australasian wren family, Maluridae.
superb-fairywren.habitat: Found in almost any area that has at least a little dense undergrowth for shelter.
superb-fairywren.diet: Mainly insectivorous, feeding on a wide range of small creatures.
funFacts: Males have a brilliant blue and black plumage during breeding season
They are socially monogamous and sexually promiscuous

rainbow-lorikeet.description: The rainbow lorikeet is a species of parrot found in Australia. It is common along the eastern seaboard, from northern Queensland to South Australia.
rainbow-lorikeet.habitat: Rainforests, coastal bushes and woodland areas.
rainbow-lorikeet.diet: Primarily nectar and pollen, but also fruits, seeds and some insects.
funFacts: Known for their bright coloration and noisy calls
They have a brush-tipped tongue for feeding on nectar

willie-wagtail.description: The willie wagtail is a passerine bird native to Australia, New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, the Bismarck Archipelago, and eastern Indonesia.
willie-wagtail.habitat: Found in most open habitats, especially around human habitation and in urban areas.
willie-wagtail.diet: Mostly insectivorous, catching insects mid-air or on the ground.
funFacts: Known for its fan-like tail that it swings from side to side
Bold for its size, often seen chasing away larger birds
